entry.title: Why are environmentalists being murdered? | Inside Story

media:group.media:title: Why are environmentalists being murdered? | Inside Story
media:group.media:description:
Around the world, environmental activists are being arrested, jailed, and even killed for trying to protect our planet. UK-based group Global Witness has recorded the highest number of murders since it began its annual survey a decade ago. 212 people were killed in 2019 for campaigning against issues such as illegal logging, mining and deforestation. 40 percent of the victims were from indigenous communities. So what's behind the rise in these attacks? And will the perpetrators be brought to justice?
Presenter: Imran Khan
Guests:
Chris Madden - Senior Campaigner at Global Witness and author of the report.
Sam Cowie - Multimedia Journalist in Brazil.
Wahyu Perdana - Campaign Manager at the Indonesian Forum for the Environment.
- Subscribe to our channel: http://aje.io/AJSubscribe - Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish - Find us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/aljazeera - Check our website: https://www.aljazeera.com/
#AlJazeeraEnglish #InsideStory #Amazon #Brazil

entry.title: Muslims begin downsized Hajj pilgrimage amid coronavirus pandemic

media:group.media:title: Muslims begin downsized Hajj pilgrimage amid coronavirus pandemic
media:group.media:description:
Hajj - the annual Muslim pilgrimage to Mecca - has begun, but under dramatically different circumstances due to the coronavirus outbreak.
One of the five pillars of Islam, the Hajj is required for all Muslims who are physically or financially capable of undertaking it at least once in their lifetime and is usually one of the world's largest religious gatherings.
But this year, only up to 10,000 people already residing in Saudi Arabia will participate in the five-day pilgrimage, a tiny fraction of the 2.5 million pilgrims from around the world that attended last year.
"There are no security-related concerns in this pilgrimage, but [downsizing] is to protect pilgrims from the danger of the pandemic," said Khalid bin Qarar Al-Harbi, Saudi Arabia's director of public security.
Pilgrims will be required to wear masks and observe physical distancing during a series of religious rites that are completed over five days in the holy city of Mecca and its surrounding areas in western Saudi Arabia.
Al Jazeera's Jamal Elshayyal reports.
- Subscribe to our channel: http://aje.io/AJSubscribe - Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish - Find us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/aljazeera - Check our website: https://www.aljazeera.com/
#AlJazeeraEnglish #Hajj #Coronavirus

entry.title: Iraqis protest over power cuts amid record summer temperatures

media:group.media:title: Iraqis protest over power cuts amid record summer temperatures
media:group.media:description:
Protesters across southern Iraq are demanding stable electricity supplies. Last week, temperatures in southern Iraq reached 54 degrees Celsius - the hottest ever recorded. The increased demand on the grid has led to frequent power cuts. Al Jazeera's Simona Foltyn reports from Baghdad.

entry.title: COVID-19 spreads in Vietnam after outbreak at tourist spot

media:group.media:title: COVID-19 spreads in Vietnam after outbreak at tourist spot
media:group.media:description:
A COVID-19 outbreak at a Vietnamese domestic tourist spot last weekend has now spread to the country’s two largest cities. The government is now bracing for another wave of the disease.
This came as Hong Kong implemented tougher measures as it too has seen a recent rise in cases.
Thailand is also looking nervously at its neighbours after these recent increases in cases of COVID-19 as the government has started to encourage internal travel and tourism to help its ailing economy.
Al Jazeera's Scott Heidler reports from Bangkok, Thailand.

#AlJazeeraEnglish #Vietnam #Coronavirus

entry.title: The Doormen of Egypt | Al Jazeera World

media:group.media:title: The Doormen of Egypt | Al Jazeera World
media:group.media:description:
From Cairo's narrow downtown streets and alleys to the affluent residential areas in the outer reaches of the city, nothing escapes the attention of the ever-vigilant doormen.
Sitting at the entrances of apartment blocks in Cairo and Alexandria - and often mindful of the chance to make a quick buck - the "bawabs" have been an integral part of the social fabric of Egypt's big cities for decades.
This Al Jazeera World documentary celebrates the men, their history, their job and their influence.
Of course, the bawabs are often much more than doormen. They are the all-seeing eyes and ears of the buildings they live and work in, observers of residents' "moral practices", as well as plumbers, electricians, security guards and keepers of personal secrets.
But today's doormen are disappearing. As a new wave of construction takes place in Cairo, Egyptian society is undergoing profound change. Many of today's doormen have become security guards, with smart blue uniforms replacing traditional galabeyas in what many see as the sad loss of a unique social group from Egypt's 20th century.

media:group.media:title: Germany investigates Wirecard's fraud case
media:group.media:description:
German prosecutors are investigating one of the largest accounting fraud cases in the country's recent history.
Wirecard was an online payment services company which crumbled into insolvency last month, after admitting that $2.2bn was missing.
Al Jazeera's Dominic Kane has more from Berlin.

entry.title: Four US ‘big tech’ CEOs to face anti-trust congressional hearing

media:group.media:title: Four US ‘big tech’ CEOs to face anti-trust congressional hearing
media:group.media:description:
The CEOs of Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google will testify together before the United States Congress on Wednesday, to defend their powerful business practices. They run companies worth a total of about $4.85 trillion. The video conference meeting is expected to be one of the most aggressive shows against technology companies in decades.
Al Jazeera’s Rob Reynolds reports from Los Angeles.

entry.title: Chile lifts COVID-19 lockdown as Latin America still hardest-hit

media:group.media:title: Chile lifts COVID-19 lockdown as Latin America still hardest-hit
media:group.media:description:
The battle to contain the coronavirus pandemic is putting pressure on nations as they seek to find a balance between public health and saving economies. After months of lockdown in Chile, the country has begun lifting restrictions in parts of the capital. But some medical experts say the government is not following recommendations from the World Health Organization.
Al Jazeera’s Lucia Newman reports from Santiago.

entry.title: Thai Police probe why Red Bull heir hit-and-run case dropped

media:group.media:title: Thai Police probe why Red Bull heir hit-and-run case dropped
media:group.media:description:
Thai police have launched an internal investigation over their handling of a high profile hit-and-run case. There has been public outcry over a perceived culture of impunity for the rich after charges were dropped against the grandson of the creator of the Red Bull energy drink. Eight years ago, he fled Thailand after a fatal crash in which a police officer was killed.
Al Jazeera’s Wayne Hay reports from Bangkok.

#Thailand #VorayuthYoovidhya #redbullheir

entry.title: Guinea protests: Demands for justice and accountability

media:group.media:title: Guinea protests: Demands for justice and accountability
media:group.media:description:
The family of a student killed last week by Guinea’s security forces say they want justice for 16-year-old Alseny Barry. He was killed in an opposition stronghold during last week's demonstrations. There have been months of protests against President Alpha Conde, demanding his resignation. The opposition says the government is using the coronavirus pandemic to crackdown on dissent.
Al Jazeera’s Priyanka Gupta reports.

#Guinea #GuineaProtests #AljazeeraEnglish

entry.title: Spain COVID-19 surge sparks fears of a second wave

media:group.media:title: Spain COVID-19 surge sparks fears of a second wave
media:group.media:description:
Coronavirus infections are soaring in parts of Spain. The city of Barcelona alone is seeing more than 1,000 new cases every day. Catalonia's leader, Quim Torra, has described the situation as critical and has said if the coronavirus outbreak is not contained in 10 days, much tougher measures will be put in place. The Spanish government is facing an uphill task convincing the world that it is a safe destination and that the latest outbreak is under control.
Al Jazeera’s Marta Herrero reports from Barcelona.

#Spain #Coronavirus #Barcelona

entry.title: US AG Barr tells Congress violent US protests must be stopped

media:group.media:title: US AG Barr tells Congress violent US protests must be stopped
media:group.media:description:
United States Attorney General William Barr has defended the harsh tactics of federal law enforcement against anti-racism protests in US cities and denied accusations he intervened in criminal cases to help President Donald Trump's allies. He testified at a congressional committee on Tuesday and faced heavy criticism for sending federal agents into cities to quash protests. He also faced accusations of politicising the Justice Department.
Al Jazeera’s Alan Fisher reports from Capitol Hill.

#BillBarr #BillBarrHearing #BillBarrTestimony

entry.title: Iran fires missile at mock US aircraft carrier during exercise

media:group.media:title: Iran fires missile at mock US aircraft carrier during exercise
media:group.media:description:
Iran has carried out military exercises in the Gulf. The drills have drawn attention because Iran’s paramilitary Revolutionary Guard is using a replica United States aircraft carrier as a target to train its troops. Al Jazeera's Assed Baig reports from Tehran.

entry.title: Has justice been done in the 1MDB scandal? | Inside Story

media:group.media:title: Has justice been done in the 1MDB scandal? | Inside Story
media:group.media:description:
For years, the 1MDB scandal has shaken Malaysia. Billions of dollars were allegedly looted from a state fund set up to promote development. A former Prime Minister was implicated as well as a network of foreign companies. Malaysia's rule of law was put to the test on Tuesday over Najib Razak's involvement. He was found guilty of all seven charges and sentenced to 12 years in prison on corruption charges . But the judge has allowed a delay in carrying out the sentence. He's also fined close to fifty million dollars. It's the first of five corruption trials and is centred on the transfer of nearly $10 million from a former unit of the fund, into Najib's personal accounts. He denies any wrongdoing, and has said he'll appeal. So, could this be a step towards rooting out corruption in Malaysia? And what, if any, are the political ramifications?
Presenter: Laura Kyle
Guests Ei Sun Oh, former Political Secretary to Najib Razak. Clare Rewcastle Brown, investigative journalist who helped to expose the 1 MDB Scandal. Bridget Welsh, honorary Research Associate at the University of Nottingham's Malaysia Campus.
- Subscribe to our channel: http://aje.io/AJSubscribe - Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish - Find us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/aljazeera - Check our website: https://www.aljazeera.com/
#AlJazeeraEnglish #Malaysia

entry.title: Malaysia sentences Najib Razak to years in prison

media:group.media:title: Malaysia sentences Najib Razak to years in prison
media:group.media:description:
Former Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak has been sentenced to serve 12 years in jail after a court in Kuala Lumpur found him guilty of corruption in the first of several cases linked to the alleged theft of billions of dollars from the state fund, 1MDB. Tuesday's ruling made Najib the first Malaysian leader to be convicted of corruption. But the 67-year-old remained free as Judge Mohamad Nazlan Ghazali granted a stay order on the execution of Najib's sentence, pending an appeal.
